last_episode_to_air.name: We Make The Game.
last_episode_to_air.overview: The Sterling scandal ushered in a new era of player empowerment, and they haven't looked back since.

name: Blackballed
overview: Highlighting five days during the 2014 NBA playoffs, when Doc Rivers, Chris Paul, DeAndre Jordan and the LA Clippers led an unprecedented movement of athletes to hold racism accountable.

episodes.name: Who Makes The Game?
episodes.overview: At the outset of the 2014 NBA playoffs, the biggest scandal in league history was about to erupt.

episodes.name: The Fish's Head.
episodes.overview: A look back at one of the worst franchises in professional sports, the Los Angeles Clippers.

episodes.name: The Tape.
episodes.overview: The Donald Sterling tape leaks. Clippers players and coaches react with shock and disgust.

episodes.name: Property.
episodes.overview: Donald Sterling's views on race extend beyond basketball and into how he ran his real estate empire.

episodes.name: Uproar.
episodes.overview: The tape creates an escalating crisis for the NBA and its new commissioner Adam Silver.

episodes.name: The Choice.
episodes.overview: In a private team meeting, Clippers players and coaches talk about the tape, race, and how to respond.

episodes.name: The Protest.
episodes.overview: The Clippers stage a protest, expressing unity and showing the world what they believe in.

episodes.name: Pressure.
episodes.overview: Pressure mounts to remove Donald Sterling from the league.

episodes.name: Bigger Than Sports.
episodes.overview: New commissioner Adam Silver makes the bold decision to ban Donald Sterling for life from the NBA.

episodes.name: Doubling Down.
episodes.overview: The Sterling scandal continues to haunt the team as their season comes to an abrupt conclusion.

episodes.name: Ousted.
episodes.overview: In dramatic tabloid fashion, the Clippers are sold to Steve Balmer, officially ending the scandal.

episodes.name: We Make The Game.
episodes.overview: The Sterling scandal ushered in a new era of player empowerment, and they haven't looked back since.
